xxl.cursors
Class Inductor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Inductor
public class Inductor
extends Object
implements Iterator

Given a tuple of start-values [a_0,...,a_n] the Inductor computes the value a_(n+1+i) (i>=0) by calling the Function next with parameters [a_i,...,a_(n+i)].
Optionally, the user can specify the Function hasNext (called with parameters [a_i,...,a_(n+i)]) which determines whether a next value exists.
With the help of an Inductor a sequence of elements can be computed represented as an Iterator.

Example usage (1): the Fibonacci sequence 

 	Inductor fibonacci = new Inductor(
 		new Object[]{new Integer(1), new Integer(1)},
 			new Function () {
 				public Object invoke (Object fib_1, Object fib_2) {
 					return new Integer(((Integer)fib_1).intValue() + ((Integer)fib_2).intValue());
 				}
 			}
 	);
 	System.out.println(Cursors.nth(fibonacci, 7));
This example computes the 7th number of the fibonacci sequence by initializing an object-array with two Integer-objects with value 1. (beginning of the induction sequence; n = 1,2)
All following elements are computed with the following function: 
 		fib(n) = fib(n-1) + fib(n-2);
This function is realized in the anonymous class Function in the method invoke. If the next element is available, i.e. the flag nextAvailable is true, the function next is invoked on the array objects.
This array is shifted left for one position by copying the values. Then the returned object is added to this array as the last element with regard to further computing of the inductor-sequence. The first element of the array objects is returned, because this is the next element in the inductor-sequence.
So this Inductor would return the next number of the fibonacci sequence as long as next is called. In this case the static method nth is used to return only the 7th number of the sequence, but also an other function hasNext can be specified in a constructor with the intention to terminate such a sequence.

Example usage (2): the factorial method 

 	Inductor factorial = new Inductor (
 		new Object[]{new Integer(1)},
 			new Function () {
 				int factor = 1;
 				public Object invoke (Object n) {
 					return new Integer(((Integer)n).intValue() * factor++);
 				}
 			}
 	);
 	System.out.println(Cursors.nth(factorial, 3));
This example computes the 3rd number of the factorial method (3! = 6).
The start-array is initialized by one Integer-object with value 1 (n = 0). Further elements are iteratively computed by invoking the above defined function: 
 		fac(n) = n * fac(n-1);
But the factor, i.e. the next integer to multiply the next element fac(n-1) by, which is written back to the array, has to be stored (in the anonymous class).

See Also:
Function, Predicate, Iterator

Field Detail

next

protected Function next
The function to compute the next element (next).

hasNext

protected Predicate hasNext
The predicate to determine an end the inductor-sequence (hasNext).

objects

protected Object[] objects
The array of start-values.

available

protected int available
The length of the given array of start-values.

nextAvailable

protected boolean nextAvailable
A flag to signal if the next element in the sequence is available. The implementation used to set this flag is as follows: 


 		nextAvailable = objects.length==available-- && hasNext.invoke(objects);
So the length of the objects array has to be the start-length, namely available, and the predicate hasNext must be true.

Inductor

                Predicate hasNext,
                Function next)
Creates a new Inductor with a user-defined predicate delivering the end of the inductor-sequence.
Parameters:
objects - the start-values [a_0,...,a_n].
hasNext - the predicate which determines wether a next value exists.
next - the function using parameters [a_i,...,a_(n+i)] (i>=0) to compute the result-value a_(n+1+i).

Inductor

public Inductor(Object[] objects,
                Function hasNext,
                Function next)
Creates a new Inductor with a user-defined (Boolean-)function delivering the end of the inductor-sequence. The (Boolean-)function hasNext is internally wrapped to a predicate.
Parameters:
objects - the start-values [a_0,...,a_n].
hasNext - the function which determines wether a next value exists.
next - the function using parameters [a_i,...,a_(n+i)] (i>=0) to compute the result-value a_(n+1+i).

Method Detail

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
Implemented by: 


 		return nextAvailable || available>0;
That means the array of start-values must no be empty and for further use the next element must be available.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Iterator
Returns:
true if the Inductor has more elements, otherwise false.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
If the next element is available, i.e. the flag nextAvailable is true, the function next is invoked on the array objects.
This array is shifted left for one position by copying the values. Then the returned object is added to this array as the last element with regard to further computing of the inductor-sequence. The first element of the array objects is returned, because this is the next element in the inductor-sequence.
Specified by:
next in interface Iterator
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

remove

public void remove()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Inductors, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
remove in interface Iterator
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the Inductor.
